block.p: LIKE Marion Jones, triathlon figures to play an outsized role in its first Olympics. It might be a niche endurance sport with a short history -- the first official triathlon was held in 1974 in San Diego -- but it is a sport at which Australians excel and which dovetails nicely with their sun-and-sea culture. That explains why triathlon has been given pride of place on the Olympic schedule. The women's event is the first gold-medal event of the Games; the men compete the next day.

LIKE Marion Jones, triathlon figures to play an outsized role in its first Olympics. It might be a niche endurance sport with a short history -- the first official triathlon was held in 1974 in San Diego -- but it is a sport at which Australians excel and which dovetails nicely with their sun-and-sea culture. That explains why triathlon has been given pride of place on the Olympic schedule. The women's event is the first gold-medal event of the Games; the men compete the next day.
THE SETUP -- A 1,500-meter swim in open water is followed by a 40-kilometer bike ride and then by a 10-kilometer run. The first across the finish line wins.

THE NAMES -- Though Americans dreamed up the triathlon, they no longer dominate. The most consistently successful man (at the Olympic distance) is Britain's Simon Lessing, a four-time world champion. His competition should come from his countryman Andrew Johns, Dmitry Gaag of Kazakhstan and the Australians Peter Robertson and Craig Walton.

The most successful women are Australians: Michelie Jones, Nicole Hackett and Loretta Harrop. In the women's event, Magali Messmer of Switzerland and Carol Montgomery of Canada are considered threats. Sheila Taormina, one of the three American women, won a gold medal in a swimming relay in Atlanta.
